SUMMARY: transcriptional dual regulator CynR, cyanate regulator, activates expression of cyn operon, which is involved in use of cyanate as a sole nitrogen source, in presence of inducer cyanate [3049588, 1592818]. It negatively regulates its own transcription independently of cyanate [1592818]. CynR belongs to family of LysR-type transcriptional regulators (LTTRs) [1592818, 8253686]. Members of this family have a conserved structure with an N-terminal DNA-binding helix-turn-helix motif and a C-terminal cofactor-binding domain. y typically form tetramers in solution that can be regarded as dimers of dimers [12706716, 19047729]. In accordance with this, CynR regulatory domain is sufficient for dimerization, whereas full-length protein behaves as a higher-order oligomer [19760662]. In systematic studies of oligomerization, it was shown that some members of LysR family, like CynR, interact with or members of family to form heterodimers, but physiological significance of this is unknown [21187915]. promoter regions for divergently transcribed cynR and cyn operons overlap. CynR binds cooperatively to a 60-bp region that contains two 9-bp repeats separated by 34 bp. binding region overlaps -35 region of promoter for cyn operon and both -10 and -35 region of its own promoter [8253686, 7961413]. CynR binds to DNA in presence or absence of cyanate and induces bending of DNA [7961413]. Cyanate decreases amount of bending, suggesting that change in bending acts as a transcriptional switch. Reviews: [2094285, 19047729].
